bibl.title: Letter from Gustaf E. Lambert to Philip Showalter Hench, April 20, 1954

div1.p: Lambert describes some of the buildings and landscape in the photographs Hench sent him. He notes that the group picture was not taken while he was there.

div1.head: Letter from Gustaf E. Lambert to Philip Showalter Hench, April 20, 1954
div1.opener:
Hazel Crest Apr. 20 - 54
Dr P. S. Hench
Dear Sir
div1.p:
I am sorry you couldn't come here as
it would have been easyer to explain
verbally then to write, but Ill do my best.
Picture A ground is right, it did slant from
rail road cut towards river, turn building
around facing building 113, remove windows
and stoop, place door at left hand corner on
flat wall, drop building to ground, raise
back 6 or 8 inches from ground, we had no
barrells down there, bridge appears to be a
heavy one, she was not there, foot bridge was
not between the houses but on side of 114 as
marked on photo b.. an coming over bridge
one could by streching out arm rub branches
of tree. Unmarked building to left of III is the
kitchen and messhall of men. About picture
of all the men I don't know what to say except
it was not taken while I was down there, we
were in quarantine 7th Cov. road gaurd
around us, I don't think they would have
allowed any photogafer in neither do I
think that a group of Doctors making a profes-
sional call would have brought a man
with them to take their picture. I know it was
not me in white uniform because I used
pajamas after the first patients left in June
of 1900 I had to burn everything and couldn't
(afford ?)
to burn my clothes, Up to the time that
West got well and Maj. Reed decided that
yellow fever was not contagious everything
was destayed. Mr Perez must have used
great imagination when he made Model
for the picture. I don't know where or
when but I've seen a surveying print
of Colubia hospital and yellow fever huts
in the lower right hand corner there were
shown in smal letters the word “Con-
templated” with an arrow pointing to-
wards the outline of four buildings, but they
were never built while I was there from
6th of June 1900 to March 13th 1901. The drawing in
Gen. Trubys book page 51 is correct except that
he added the contemplated buildings 17-18-19-20
after reading Gen. Trubys manuscript I drew
his attention to the mistake, but he answered
Dr Pinto said so, who was I to argue with the
Gen? But I lived down there 10 1/2 months and I
should know. I've corresponded with Mrs
Jernegan since 1919 at one time she must
have felt blue she wrote she would be willing
to give five years of her life if she could sit for
one hour again with her husband on the
steps of the lith but, I then wrote and asked her
if she could remember how many houses there
were down there, I enclose her answers, the
Jernegans were at quemados a year and a
halve after me
div1.closer:
Very Respectfully Gust E Lambert over
Ac
In to L
will gladly come downtown when
my legs get a litle stronger if called
